entries.title: OSDC New Zealand
entries.text: I've just heard about the OSDC (Open Source Developers Conference) that will take place between 21-23 October, 2013 in Auckland, New Zealand. Sounds like fun!

entries.title: eCommerce Innovations 2013
entries.text: Stefan Hornburg (Racke) wrote about the eCommerce conference he is organizing in October 9-11, 2013 at the West Branch Resort in Hancock, NY: 'Speakers well known to the Interchange community are covering Interchange 5/6, Dancer, Modern Perl and modules related to eCommerce like Business::OnlinePayment.'

entries.title: We're Hiring Telecommuters - Grant Street Group
entries.text:

entries.title: Introducing Moops
entries.text: As Toby Inkster writes, 'Moops is sugar for writing object-oriented Perl. It provides similar syntax to MooseX::Declare and Stevan Little's p5-mop-redux'. It is certainly an interesting experiment.

entries.title: Update on the adoption list - first adoption!
entries.text: In case you were wondering how can you start contributing to an open source project, or which project to pick, Neil Bowers has updated the list he generates. Check it out as this can help you picking a module for yourself.

entries.title: Cooperative module maintenance?
entries.text: I found four Perl-related 'github organizations' where several people maintain a few Perl modules together. If you know about more organizations, please let me know. If you are lookiing for module to contribute to, but you prefer working together with others, then checking out these modules might be bettet than the list Neil Bowers generates. Or, you could take one of the modules from the list of Niels and bring it to a Github organization.

entries.title: How to add images to the documentation of Perl modules on CPAN
entries.text: Another way to contribute to CPAN would be to add relevant images (screenshots, graphs etc.) to the documentation of modules. It's rather easy.

entries.title: Perl Catalyst "Hamburg" Development Release 002 on CPAN
entries.text: If you use Catalyst, it is worth following the posts of John Napiorkowski. You can easily install it from CPAN using cpanm and try if this version does not break any of your code.

chapters.title: Tiny C Compiler
chapters.header: The Tiny C Compiler is a small, fast, nearly C99 compliant C compiler written for Linux and Windows, which can also compile object code on Mac. The other day David Mertens has released  C::TinyCompiler and blogged about it. When Steffen Mueller saw this, he also went ahead and pushed his version of the idea, called XS::TCC to CPAN. Now we have two modules that allow you to compile C code on the fly, and hopefully some cooperation between the authors.

entries.title: C::TinyCompiler, a just-in-time C compiler for Perl

chapters.title: Events
chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
